Award.AwardTitle: Noyce Professional Development for Future STEM Educators at UTK

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Robert Noyce Phase 1 project represents a partnership between the University of Tennessee, Knoxville's (UTK) VolsTeach four-year, two-career path program (a UTeach replicate), the National Institute for Math and Biological Synthesis, Anderson County Schools, Roane County Schools, and Knox County Schools. It is a collaborative effort between content area professionals in math and science, teacher educators, a national institute emphasizing the quantitative nature of science, and three school systems in communities under economic distress. Over the course of the project 45 Internships are supporting freshman and sophomore student service in a variety of educational outreach activities, while 42 Noyce scholarships are supporting a select group of junior and senior VolsTeach students.

Intellectual Merit: Two key components of the project designed to improve the quality of the teachers the program prepares are: a Noyce Research Methods course to equip the Scholars for engaging their future students in STEM inquiry, and a monthly Noyce Seminar Series on STEM Issues that is broadly advertised to encourage participation from a variety of stakeholders including experienced and novice teachers, those preparing to be teachers, faculty in the sciences, math and education and the interested public. Formative and summative assessments are being conducted on all aspects of the project.

Broader Impact. The program is providing quality teachers in STEM disciplines to school systems that most need them. These teachers have a strong foundation in engaging students in inquiry learning, including experience with cooperative learning and model research systems that support high school student math and science literacy and its application to technology. In addition the Noyce Scholars are being supported during their early years as teachers thus ensuring they will be able to implement creative teaching methods in STEM in the high-need schools where they will serve. Information about the project, particularly the research methods course, is being disseminated statewide and nationally in publications, conference presentations, and other communications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our Noyce Professional Development for Future Stem Educators at UTK project's goal has been to help undergrads in our new VolsTeach program to maximize the skill development required of effective teachers in STEM disciplines so that they will have long professional careers educating students of all socioeconomic, linguistic, cultural and racial backgrounds. While a major concern is the lack of teachers trained in STEM disciplines, we also desired to ensure that our VolsTeach graduates thoroughly understand and can convey to their students the nature and exciting process of scientific inquiry and its interdisciplinary nature. We thus offered them two special experiences developed under the auspices of this grant: a research methods course and a STEM lecture series. 

 

  • Under Research Methods, teams composed of a mix of math and science students identify, devise and carry out such STEM projects such as: Barking up a Complex Tree: A Methodological and Mathematical Journey into the Realm of the Common Dog Bark; “Nicotine: Is it as “Fly” as You Think: Its Effects on Drosophila; Paddling Through the Pollution:  Comparative Analyses of Water Quality levels in Local Creeks; Investigating Division of a Prokaryotic cell (E. coli bacteria); and Physics: It’s a Drag! An Investigative Study on the Drag Force of Roller Coasters. This course has also led to the generation of a 170 page book of suggested areas of investigation for High School STEM classes.

 

  • Our STEM issues seminar series serves to reinforce all aspects of a student’s experiences under VolsTeach and engages them with others in academic discussion of current issues in STEM and STEM Education that they will encounter and deal with in their teaching. Examples of the seminar series include: “Addressing the Problem of Climate Change”, “Teaching Evolution”; and “Advice from the Field -Teaching STEM Effectively in Schools Serving Economically Distressed Communities”.

This program helps undergraduate STEM majors progress through a minor in teacher education at the same time they complete their major degree program. Thus, they earn a bachelor’s degree in their major, a minor in education, and teacher certification within four years, largely under the guidance of PhD master teachers hired as clinical faculty.  VT students progress through teaching experiences with K-8 students in two introductory courses before admittance to the VolsTeach Program and more advanced course work, including the Research Methods Course mentioned above. VolsTeach has already graduated 62 secondary ed math and science secondary teachers in its five years of existence. The majority have had Noyce internship support as they served in such roles as instructional assistants, Biology in a Box Project development of K-12 exercises, Knoxville Zoo and Children’s Museum of Oak Ridge Assistants and STEM tutors for high school students. In addition, 24 of our VolsTeach students have been the recipients of Noyce Scholarships.

 

The external evaluators of this project summarized their review as follows: “The components of the VolsTeach Noyce program provide an effective model for attracting and retaining STEM teachers. And the internships, Research Methods Course, and the seminar series lay a foundation of professional development activities that cultivate effective teachers with strong content, pedagogy, and team skills.”
